>we have been so conditioned to go home and be in our own little worlds, 'unwinding' through social media that we don't interact with our friends between catching up as much as we should. texting/social media feels so unreal/fake compared to calling, which is basically taboo with zoomers. the only exception is discord calls/game parties, which my friends are not into
>it's considered exceptionally weird, almost rude, to show up unannounced and knock on the door/ask someone if your friend is in - when I was a kid in late 2000s this wasn't the case, I'd ride my bike over to my friends house and see if they were there. it all changed overnight when we got phones as teens.
>the fact that I only have three friends says a lot. i've tried a bunch of this board's suggestions: meetups organised online are usually lates 20s at the youngest, while uni/college is a meme for zoomers - clubs are filled with a rotating door of first years who later disappear, and everyone disappears into their phones between classes and doesn't want to be bothered. meanwhile, church is mostly for older people and the few young people there have an impenetrable group that you'll never break into

>>28074393
It's been a long time since I thought about this issue. but generally I would say.

Create public spaces where people can gather, a few different but overlapping types that are easily accessible
Teach people a standard social norm and basic rules, to prevent misunderstandings the devolve in to messes
Dispel the illusion of power we have as a consumer culture. (i.e. Buying things is not the answer. Show that skills are more valuable and those skills can be grown in a community setting were people help learn from each other.)
Remove and adjust incentives for dual income family structures, and focus legitimately on the future and the children. (As more and more move to dual income family structures to make more money and thus allowing prices to inflate, it has created huge costs for non-monitory actions like raising kids or forming communities. Someone has to spend the time to raise kids, build the future and foster communities, but structurally those critical people are not rewarded so people stop doing those things).
Localize markets and economies. (Yes, it will cost more money and be less convenient, but it will help deal with many other issues from disaster preparedness to general happiness as people can better see the value of their work)
Shift to localize comparisons, or better yet none at all. (Your hear the stories, comparing yourself to other just hurts you. And now with the internet and such we compare ourselves with the whole world, which is often staged.)

I remember as a kid there was a nice park and playground at the center of the neighborhood full of kids my age. My Mom pushed me to play there and got me all kinds of gear, but I just kept begging for an N64 and Cartoon network access. Because I was ostracized for not knowing anything about popular things like Majora's Mask or Dragon Ball Z, as I would sit on a park bench with a whole baseball equipment set and nobody to play with. So alone I was as the way I was taught to played was outdated.

Get out and talk to people, build a network. Most people hate the way things are, but don't act because they don't have a actionable solution or even know where to start. So get out there and correctly* identify the problem and then help build a solution, once people know about a better way they often will help out and then things really take off. (*seen way too many people think they know the problem, but never actual see it first hand or talk to those involved, thus bad disconnects happen and every just gets angry)
find people already working on these things and volunteer, learn and grow from there. You not alone, you just don't know who is on your team yet.
If you can deal with the high stress, get political. You would be shocked at how one person can affect a local political body, heck you could end up on the committee given how few apply for those jobs.
Solutions are needed on both the big and small scale. But if you can get a viral small scale win, then many more will ask how to copy your success and things can grow. Or somehow make it to congress and work to fix the large mess, that kind of a life's work deal most can't pull off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28072859
>But are there guys out there who will wait?
Yes. They're rare, but they definitely exist. It can get demoralizing at first to see a lot of guys just leave if they hear they won't get free sex, but from what I've heard from the couple femanons on here who found their partners this way (and what I'm convinced of myself), it's well worth the patience once you do find that special someone.

The silver lining of it being rare also means that the people who do wait both stand out and tend to really mean it. The latter tends to select for quality (at least for people who are honest and committed to their ideals), while the former makes it easier to meet others doing the same.
Even if you meet some people who aren't willing or able to wait while you are dating, you will still grow your social network in the process. And since you'll stand out for having a different way of dating, if anyone who knows you comes across a guy who stands out in the same way, they might make the connection between you two.

There are two things to keep in mind, though.
First, while some guys might agree to wait initially, especially if it wasn't what they intended to do to begin with, they might try to push for a "compromise" that totally defeats the purpose of waiting. As in, they'll press for something sexual but that isn't 'technically' sex. It's just another way of them getting their fill without any commitment, so watch out.
Second, a social network only helps if the people in it are genuine and non-judgmental towards you. If they're the kinds of people to try to make you feel like a freak for waiting, who say you should just give up because it's too rare, or something along those lines, it'll be a headache for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
because your brain isn't over-producing dopamine, oxytocin and endorphins every time you look at her anymore. the initial stages of infatuation means that she could pick her nose in front of you and it would probably still be exciting- maybe an exaggeration, but you get what i mean.

infatuation is neurochemically identical to a hit of cocaine. it's designed to facilitate pair bonding, since it's easier to form an attachment to someone who makes you feel good just from looking at them. this doesn't last forever, though, as your brain can't sustain automatically generating its own cocaine for more than two years maximum.

after that, it's in your hands. you say she's your best friend, and that's good. means you picked someone you can tolerate without your brain drenched in pleasure hormones, which is more than a lot of people can say. the other bit of good news is you can still stimulate that pleasurable response, but it's going to take some effort to provoke it. novelty is usually the best way to do so. trying out new sex positions, toys, making your own homemade porn together, going on dates to new places, travelling. when you first met her everything was new. you've gotten used to her now, probably fallen into comfortable habits. if you miss the excitement, then create situations that excite you.

posts.sub: Advice for getting ADHD diagnosis as adult?
posts.com:
I'm seeing a psychiatrist next week to discuss the possibility that I might have ADHD.
I have pretty much all the symptoms aside from hyperactivity (although I do fidget and pick at my nails constantly when trying to sit still, watching a movie is impossible unless its very good).

What do I need to do/say and what shouldn't I say?

I do have school reports I can bring, many of which mention some variation of 'needs to work more to complete tasks', some mention that I'm poorly organised and often fail to bring equipment to class, although other reports don't mention anything at all and are just 'he's okay but needs encouragement'-copypastas. I used to day dream and fidget a LOT during school, so I'm surprised they don't mention that. Should I not bring the school reports then? Or Should I only bring the ones that seem relevant?

After high school I took 2 years as a NEET, then it took me 5 years to graduate with a Bsc and I'm just now starting my first full-time job at the age of 26. It seems like I'm doing okay now but the reality is that I'm not at all able to keep up with my job. I often 4-5 hours a day at my job just picking at my nails or doing 2 minutes of work before spacing out.

I can't even follow along in meetings or 1 on 1 chats with my scrum master for more than a minute so obviously this position isn't tenable for very long without treatment.

Getting treatment is a necessity now, I wish I could have got onto this sooner but life's been such a rollercoaster ride that I haven't had the time or money, or motivation to push my self to see a psych until now, and now my livelihood depends on getting a diagnosis/treatment..
Any advice would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.com: i've spent a lot of time dealing with these parasites so let me clue you in on a few things. first off, those letters are basically bullshit. there are templates you can find online that effectively state "i did not agree to this debt and i am not responsible", and if you send it to them within 30 days of the first notice, they'll be unable to do anything. even if you don't respond at all, they're trying to collect a debt that isn't worth enough to pursue in court, so they know they can't get it out of you. eventually they'll send you a new letter with a reduced price offer, allowing you to pay off the debt anywhere as low as 30% of the initial amount. if you still refuse, they'll notify the credit bureaus, at whoch point you make an account on something like credit karma, locate the report, and file a dispute. say you have no idea where the charges came from and you did not approve this. they'll take it off your record 90% of the time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28072586
Ah, hallucinations. The problem with hallucinations isn't sensory stuff, it's ideas and impulses.
Much like how you can feel bugs crawling on your skin that aren't really there, you can also get beliefs that seem real when they aren't, and desires that seem real when they aren't related to reality either.
It's one thing to hallucinate some random ass demon telling you to die, you'd just ignore the demon since you know it's sus. It's another thing to hallucinate up the impulse to kill yourself, or to believe it's necessary and important for you to kill yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28072663
For instance, this.
If you keep hallucinating that something _does_ make sense, and that you _were_ told that knowledge before you could've known it.
Then it doesn't matter that you were told something different (or told some random gibberish), because you'll mistakenly judge the old gibberish as true, sensible, relevant, and prescient.
And as I understand it, people undergoing psychosis are incapable of noticing that these hallucinatory judgements are hallucinations. If the psychosis tells them that something is important and justified, they can't not believe it.

>try to go to a social event 1-2x a week - schoolfags will tell you college/uni can solve this (but in my experience it is far, far, far from being a silver bullet for social isolation). jobs can be good depending on your coworkers, with a wagie job it's really 'luck of the draw' as they're entry-level and not specialised to your interests/qualifications. most of my success has been from meetup groups you can find online for your interests (rock climbing, dnd, whatever you want), finding the occasionally interesting person, becoming friends with them, and becoming friends with their friends and so on
>save up between $5-10k for a 'rainy day'
>move out of your mother's place when you have six months of expenses in advance put aside (other than the savings above)

first of all, it's hard to tell what's relevant to you because I don't know what country you're in. I am in australia and this is what i have been doing over the past few years.
secondly, yes, this will likely take you years - as they say, rome was not built in a day. try to come up with a five-year plan for yourself.

posts.sub: how i found peace after attemping suicide
posts.com:
hey guys. hope you're doing well.

on november 2nd, 2021, i attempted suicide. i took as many pills as i could get my hands on. obviously i did a shitty job. i spent months in the hospital and more time in a state mental hospital, which was honestly more traumatic than the suicide attempt.

but i'm still here. last month my girlfriend cheated on me, and i lost my job because my boss went bankrupt and i still haven't been paid. but strangely enough, i am happier than i have ever been. this peace came from a simple thought i had, and it's changed my life for the better.

it hasn't made me money, or helped pay my bills. it hasn't brought me love. but it has brought me peace, and i'm so grateful to be alive.

essentially, it just boils down to this: everything you experience, every aspect of reality is a subjective interpretation of reality. the entire world as you know it exists entirely inside your own mind. you don't know if this is a dream, if you're in a coma, or the matrix. your brain is just gathering an endlessly complex mix of input from your senses, and putting it together in your head into what you think is "reality."

you and everybody else, from the most powerful people in the world to the man face down in the gutter, are stuck inside your head. no amount of money, sex, power, influence, intelligence, anything will change that. all you have right now is what you're experiencing physically,. that's it.

the past and the future are just ideas. nothing exists outside of what is around you here and now. physically. sensory. .

forget the job. money and jobs are just things we made up to pass the time here. forget the girl, she's trapped in her head just like you, trying her best. maybe people are spiteful, maybe things hurt. trust me, i know. i've spent time in jail, time in a psych ward, and time passed out on the floor while my younger brother called an ambulance. i spent years in a drunken, drug-addled stupor just trying to forget i was alive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
none of it is real. you know what is real? the warmth of the sun on your face. the sound of good music. the taste of good coffee, or a good burger. the burn of bourbon in the back of your throat. the ache in your chest when you watch the sunset on the last day of summer.

yes, there will be hard days. things will hurt. you will be sad, angry, cold, bruised, abused, and eventually you will die. but you can forget everything, everything else but what is right here. that is how you stay alive. that is how you stay here.

don't lose yourself to things that exist only in your mind. even pleasure, pain, sensory things are just electrochemical impulses your brain comes up with. nobody is here on purpose. nobody asked to be here. have some patience for yourself. have some patience for others. we are all existing without our consent, we are all trapped inside our own minds, just trying our best. cut through all the bullshit. do only what you want, what makes you feel alive. nothing else matters. you are beholden to nobody.

breathe in. breathe out. put some music on. have a beer, a cig. and at the very least, don't kill yourself. it'll be over before you know it anyway. you may as well stick around and enjoy the pretty lights, the noise and quiet, the pain and pleasure. because this is all you have, this is all anybody has ever had and ever will have.

we are a world full of dumb kids, trying to make sense of a universe that doesn't make any. nobody has figured it out. nobody ever has. we're all just pretending. but it's okay to laugh at this cosmic joke, even if you don't get it.

cheers.

Waiting until marriage is the only thing that explicitly places commitment above sex. If OP wants to be with only one woman in his life, and have her say the same, waiting until marriage is the only standard which can consistently deliver.

My Ex is having a hard time dealing with dealing with the end of our relationship about a year ago. I made peace and moved on pretty quickly with dating and met my current GF. In the meantime I've still tried to be a good friend to my Ex and be there for her because she has been dealing with a lot of personal and family issues and I told her even when I we broke up I would be a friend and support her.

My current GF and I have been in a relationship for about 6 months now. When I first introduced her to my Ex, they didn't quite get along. I know in her own way she was just trying to look out for me but sometimes she gets a little too passionate and protective but I basically told her to knock it off and figured I had it settled.

Well I didn't know this until recently, but my Ex has been harassing and making threats to my GF. This is kind of complicated by the fact that my Ex is also a police detective and she took things too far. My GF actually has voicemails, texts, and emails and finally had enough and is now threatening to file a complaint against my Ex which could ruin her career. My Ex broke down the other day begging her not to, and I also was trying to convince her not to do it, that we should just let this all be done with and let everyone walk away unharmed.

Basically my GF is fucking pissed with me accusing me of taking my Ex's side, but I'm not! I'm just trying to negotiate a good ending to this feud and let us all walk away from this and move on. How am I the bad guy here? What my Ex did was obviously stupid and wrong, but I'm just trying to get my GF to see reason and not do anything hasty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>> In the meantime I've still tried to be a good friend to my Ex and be there for her because she has been dealing with a lot of personal and family issues

This is the whole and entire problem. This and nothing else. Everything you have described here stems from the mixed messages you're sending everyone from doing this.

Tell your EX to take a hike. You're not doing her any favours by remaining in her life. No, she doesn't need you. No it isn't complicated. No, emotional blackmail isn't a reason to stick around. Lose the ex, or lose the current gf and just get back with the ex. Choose, you can't have both.

Yes, you're the bad guy here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28073837
The easiest way is to get into crypto is to open a Coinbase account and purchase the crypto of your choice through there (highly recommend Bitcoin and only Bitcoin). Get ready to send them a picture of your driver's license though, they're pretty particular about KYC (know your customer) over there.

As for wallets, the most accessible wallet for people new to crypto is Exodus. It runs right on your computer, just make sure to write down your pass key somewhere in case you need to restore it in the case of a catastrophic event. It would also be good practice to send the crypto which you purchase to your Exodus wallet first and then send it to his, that way you get some experience with it yourself.

I wouldn't worry so much about learning how to trade it. It's probably much safer, with the market where is, to just buy it and sit on it for a few years. Attempting to gauge the market is mostly luck for new people and even most professional traders lose regularly.

By the way, I have a random question for you: does the word Fenovir have any meaning to you? You may be someone I ran into a couple years ago on here.

I am so sorry you're going through this. This will be the hardest challenge of your life. Without knowing your circumstances, I PROMISE you that you will be able to get through this, and life will still have meaning after. But it's going to be very painful and it might take years to work through this.
Is hospice care an option for her? They might be better equipped than you are to help her be comfortable. You've done so much already, you've cared for her as best as you can. You deserve support and help and relief. It might be a better option for both of you.
I am sorry to say this. You're going to loose her soon. She'll be gone. The love she had for you her entire life won't be gone. The good she did, the memories, the hope - that is going to keep living with you. Through your actions and your memories and who you are. But her life on earth will be over soon. And you'll have to come to terms with that, as hard as it is.
I would encourage you to see if your work, your church, the hospital, (or any other community you have) have resources for this situation. Many places offer free counseling, estate planning, chaplain services. You need help. This is too much for you to fight alone. And that doesn't mean anything is wrong with you. This would hurt anyone, no matter how strong.
Wishing you and your family the very best. This is going to hurt very badly, and for a long time. You might not believe this now, but this won't destroy your life. You can still be happy, find fulfillment, and overcome this. It will take a long, long time. But never give up. Never, never, never give up. Her love for you, and your love for her, are NOT dying now. The end of a life is not the end of love.
Condolences.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28073877
Pretty much what it sounds like. I cook 6 nights a week and I keep pre-prepared ingredients that make it easy to throw good meals together in 15-20 mins.

e.g. Every couple of months I buy two whole chickens, break them down, use the bones to make stock. I poach and shred some of the chicken breast to toss into stir fries and salads. Or if I'm making white rice I'll make a bit extra to put in the fridge so that I can use it for fried rice. And I've got my stock in the freezer that's good for a quick noodle soup.

I don't have my fridge stacked with precooked foods or anything. It's mostly about planning ahead a bit and preparing extra protein or vegetables if I know I'm going to use them again tomorrow night.

Also an underrated part of the whole deal is that I grow tonnes of fresh herbs, chillies, spring onion, and celery on my balcony in pots. Always having herbs on hand saves heaps of money and I use them by the fistful, whereas I'd probably only buy them for special occasions if I always had to purchase bunches of them from the supermarket.

27M, single for a couple of months now.

I know I'm not ready for a relationship yet, but I still want to go out and meet/connect with people, as well get the physical touch, whether it's just cuddling, kissing or hooking up with.

What's the best way to navigate the dating scene (city) with this information? I've had 3 exes and some sexual encounters in the past but idk I just feel like I'm so bad at "the chase" or "the game". How I've ended up with these experiences feels like flukes where I wasn't even certain I knew what I was doing.

I like to be forward from the beginning about where I am in my life and what I hope to get out of a relation/ship so that the girl I'm speaking to can set expectations, and I feel it's a good first impression if my actions are honest. But instead it feels like I just put all my cards on the table and then they don't like that. But I also don't want to feel like I'm leading someone on? Idk how to properly "play the cards" and slowly reveal myself

I realize this post is a little all over the place I'm just confused

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Just have fun and those more serious conversations will happen over time if they naturally happen. If you have just met someone they don't want to know all your cards because they have their own shit going on and being too open with people too soon is often a red flag.

But on the other hand you can just be very open and you will find people who will appreciate that too it's just more likely that most people take things a bit slower.

I get that "have fun" is very generic but it just means do those fun things you're talking about like romance and touch but don't invest a lot early on and don't feel like you need to spill the beans in the first conversations. There will be milestones where the cards are to be revealed and those will be when either you or your partner are too curious to not ask to see the cards but no one cares in the first few weeks of dating/hooking up because even though you're friendly with each other in the end you're still strangers that early on.

It's very much like plutonic friendships you don't just tell everyone everything the first few times you meet up but that can be confusing because sex is inherently intimate. You also may just be someone who can't separate sex/affection from a loving relationship which is normal too and you might have to take things slower and have your card-showing conversations before engaging in anything sexual.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28073182
Being tender is for committed relationships because it's very vulnerable for yourself if things don't work out.

That doesn't mean be a jerk or don't be a gentleman but I know what you mean by tenderness and that has to be limited because if you keep giving that away too soon you can really get hurt. Again you can be nice to people and respectful and still spoon them and hug them and all that but that next level tenderness is something you should reserve a bit. Make it clear that you're capable of such tenderness but that you also respect that quality of yourself enough to not just give it to anyone because it's something special if you're able to have that quality as a man but in the beginning remember you're still strangers and until some commitment has been made that tenderness should be reserved. Hopefully that makes sense, that tenderness is the next level that people in successful relationships talk about really solidifying their bonds but people don't want to be bonded immediately for the most part.

Again some do want bonds before sexual intimacy and that's something you need to decide for yourself if it's something you need before engaging in sex and if so communicate that with any partners.

All the best man you'll do great, protect your tenderness.

posts.com: I became a father at 23, I'm 30 now and on my third child, so I can tell you anything you want to know. General advice though? Get lots of sleep. Sleep whenever you can, especially when they do. If you become sleep deprived and have to wake up at 4am to feed a screaming child you will go off the deep end. Don't waste money and space on stuff like changing table, bottle warmers, etc. You'll quickly owarn that throwing thwm on the bed to change a diaper or whatever is better than storing, cleaning and maintaining a bunch of bullshit. Babies really need very little to be happy and comfortable. Always be loud around them when they sleep or they'll turn into a light sleeper. Never feed them honey, it can kill them. Never use tylenol unless absolutely necessary, it causes autism. Keep them clean, always give a bath and lotion before bed. Otherwise, watch them carefully, love them, be a good dad. One day they'll be taking care of you.

Pregnancy isnt bad. Shes just sick a bunch. At minimum, read or listen to “Dude, You’re Gonna be a Dad.”

Apply to daycare now. Everywhere has enormous waitlists.

Take baby cpr/baby health class, generally given by the hospital.

Have the nursery built a month before due date because kids can come early.

Your life will be generally the same until kiddo starts crawling.

Nanite is worth it. Wifi is extremely nice because you can check in from work. Get the nicer one because low resolution means that you can tell if they are breathing, which is a pain.

Pump breast milk into small bags. Heating up a full bottle only for kiddo to drink a little bit and waste the rest is painful.

Multiple pacifiers in the crib.

Baby led weaning is better than Gurber.

There is never a good reason to cheat anon. If you are unhappy and you actually love and trust the person you are with, talk to them about it and see if it's something you can fix together. If not, go your separate ways. It's not okay to start an emotional or physical relationship with another person while you are still involved in a committed relationship.
If you're a guy, you're basically forced to accept that she is more social than you. She will probably want nights out with girlfriends and have guy friends too. You have to trust her and not keep tabs on her/check her phone/check up on her online unless she has given you a VERY good reason to.
Other than that, just love her and be supportive of her. Communicate well, have fun, try new and exciting things together as often as you can.
If she cheats on you after all of that, that's entirely on her because you did everything that you could to be a good partner and she was just selfish, damaged goods or morally bankrupt.
At that point feel free to completely cut her out of your life and never talk to her again. No rants about how much she hurt you, she knows what she did and what she gave up in the process. Never, EVER let her weasel her way back into your life when the new guy does the old "pump and dump."

posts.com:
>What are the chances that my past actions online will come back to haunt me?
It's 0% if you don't let it.

The way you heal from trauma is that you have to get immediate closure as soon as possible; and as you grow, things are inclined to be action oriented than by situation.

***

To expound mathematically(I apologize for the mathematical gibberish, you can fast forward to the conclusion):
What do you think is the value of a day for a three year old compared to a day for a 45 year old looks like?

a. 1 day for a three year old is (1÷365)÷3 = 0.000913242009132 or around 0.09%

b. 1 day for a 45 year old is (1÷365)÷45 = 0.000060882800609 or only 0.006%

***

Now the above check for a few things:
1. Now if you take both their values and appropriate, a day for three year old is 14.999999999950726 or 15 times more valuable than a day for a 45 year old. Following this, whatever happens on the young person's day increases in magnitude dramatically in comparison to someone who is older: happiness, fear, sadness, hate, bravery, etc.

2. A day can be two days, a week, a month(prolonged events such as a sprain, breaking a leg, depression) - this will alter the calculation significantly which is why closure has to be attained properly. The longer you are held by something, the more valuable it becomes(this applies to happiness as well).

3. This is also the math to "Time heals all things(almost)", the older you get the more insignificant an event will grow. The best thing you can do about something bad that happened is proper closure and simply live a long life.
